titleStmt.title: Stability and Stabilization for Singular Switching Semi-Markovian Jump Systems With Generally Uncertain Transition Rates

analytic.title: Stability and Stabilization for Singular Switching Semi-Markovian Jump Systems With Generally Uncertain Transition Rates

biblStruct.note: This article has been accepted for publication in a future issue of this journal, but has not been fully edited. Content may change prior to final publication. Citation information: DOI 10.1109/TAC.2018.2819654, IEEE Transactions on Automatic Control

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This paper studies the problems of stability and stabilization for a class of singular switching Semi-Markovian jump systems. The general transition rates in the Semi-Markov process cover completely unknown and uncertain bounded as two special cases. Firstly, sufficient conditions are developed to ensure the unforced system to be regular, impulse-free and exponentially mean-square stable; Then, by proposing a state feedback controller, sufficient conditions in terms of strict linear matrix inequalities are derived to guarantee the closed-loop system to be stochastically stabilziable. Finally, a numerical example is provided to show the effectiveness of the obtained results.

div.head: I. INTRODUCTION
div.p: In many real world systems, switching systems are the typical ones that can be used to model a variety of physical systems, for example, computer controlled systems and communication systems, etc. Over the past few decades, switched systems received great attention may be motivated by the fact that they reflect the characteristic of switching between system structures on one aspect and the idea of switching controllers are more effective than single controller to handle complex systems on the other. For switched systems, at each instant of time, one of the subsystems will be activated along the system trajectory. However, due to the abrupt phenomena such as component failure and parameter shifting, the subsystem is more suitably described by Markov jump system (MJS). Thus the system which combined a series of linear subsystems of continuous-time or discrete-time subjects to both stochastic jumps and deterministic switches is then dubbed as switching MJS which was firstly proposed by [1], in which the motivation is to study the stability and control of a failureprone system managed by a supervisor whose actions are This work is supported by the National Natural Science Foundations of China (No.61473097), and the authors gratefully acknowledge financial support from the China Scholarship Council (No. 201706330003).

B. Jiang is with the School of Mathematical Sciences, Ocean University of China, Qingdao 266100, China and with Department of Mechanical Engineering, Politecnico di Milano, 20156 Milan, Italy (e-mail: baopingj@163.com) Y. Kao is with the Department of Mathematics, Harbin Institute of Technology (Weihai), Weihai, 264209, China (e-mail: ygkao2008@gmail.com) H.R. Karimi is with the Department of Mechanical Engineering, Politecnico di Milano, 20156 Milan, Italy (email: hamidreza.karimi@polimi.it) C. C. Gao is with the School of Mathematical Sciences, Ocean University of China, Qingdao 266100, P.R. China (e-mail: ccgao@ouc.edu.cn) to select the appropriate feedback regulator among a finite set of alternatives. Another example is arose in networked control with deterministically switching control laws and stochastic jumps in the level of network congestion [2]. To our knowledge, up to date, only a few limited works have reported on this kind of switching MJSs besides [1,2]. For instance, exponential l 2 -l ∞ stochastic/finite-time stability and stabilization problems for discrete-time and continuous-time switching MJSs were analyzed in [3,4].

Compared with MJS, where the sojourn-time h is a random variable follows continuous probability distribution F , namely exponential distribution, Semi-Markovian jump system (S-MJS) would better reflect the specifications of practical systems than MJS. It can be found that the sojourn-time h may follow some other probability distributions rather than an exponential distribution. More specifically, in S-MJSs, the transition rates (TRs) can be time varying instead of being constant, which also means MJSs are a special class of S-MJSs. Recently, S-MJSs have received increasing attention which cover the basic analysis regarding to the stability and control strategies in [5][6][7][8]. Particularly, consider the stability of S-MJSs studied by Huang [9], in which less conservative results were proposed by partitioning the range of the sojourntime h. Further, in [10], Huang applied the sojourn-time partition technique to investigate H ∞ state-feedback control for S-MJLSs with time-varying delays. Also, noting that in [11], the stability analysis and the state feedback control were firstly proposed for nonlinear descriptor S-MJSs. While in contrast to substantial results for Markovian switching systems [12][13][14][15], the research efforts given to S-MJSs were still limited, especially for switching systems with time-delay, which is caused by external and internal factors such as the influence of incubation and measurement sensor delay. So, it is of great practical and theoretical significance to further investigate the analysis and design problems of S-MJLSs with time-delay considering its wide application area.

On the other hand, for jumping systems, the transition rates play an important role in the system behavior. Often, it is difficult to acquire the precise value of TRs for MJSs, and most existing results regarding MJLSs are based on the absolute acquired information on TRs. There are also related results concerning uncertain information on TRs in the jumping processes. For example, stability and stabilization of MJSs with partly unknown transition probabilities were investigated in [16][17][18][19]; and stabilization of singular MJSs with generally uncertain TRs was studied in [19]. It can be seen from the above results are confined in MJSs whose TRs are constant. So far, no results have been reported on how to deal with generally uncertain TRs in S-MJSs, which partly motivated us to do this research.

In this paper, the problem of stability and stabilization is first proposed for singular switching S-MJSs. Different from some existing results in literature, the modeling of uncertain TRs matrix is much more reasonable and less conservative, such as compared with [19], in which the assumptions on uncertain TRs are too strict, also, this modeling method provides easy analysis for the subsequent system stability property. By selecting an appropriate Lyapunov function, which is allowed to increase in the same mode and at the switching instants simultaneously, a good property of exponential mean-square stability is analyzed for the considered system. And, we propose sufficient conditions that are less conservative and strict solvable LMIs even thought these TRs are time-varying and uncertain to ensure exponential mean-square stability. Then, a novel state feedback controller is designed to guarantee stabilization purpose, and the existence of the novel designed controller can be obtained by solving feasible LMIs. Finally, a numerical example is provided to illustrate our proposed results.

Notions: The notation X > 0 (X ≥ 0) means that X is a symmetric positive definite (semi-positive definite) matrix. I and 0 are used to represent an identity matrix and zero matrix of appropriate dimensions, respectively. ∥•∥ refers to the Euclidean vector norm or spectral matrix norm. (Ω, F, P) is a probability space. The symmetric elements of the symmetric matrix are denoted by * .

div.head: II. PROBLEM STATEMENT AND PRELIMINARIES
div.p: Consider the following singular switching system fixed on the probability space
div.formula: E ẋ(t) = A(g t , r t )x(t) + A d (g t , r t )x(t -d) + B(g t , r t )u(t) x(t + θ) = φ(θ), ∀θ ∈ [-d, 0],(1)
div.p: where x(t) ∈ R n is the state vector and u(t) ∈ R p is the control input. φ(θ) is the initial condition defined on [-d, 0]. g t is the deterministic switching signal taking values in a finite set S 1 = {1, 2, . . . , N 1 }. r t is a continuous-time Semi-Markov process taking values in a finite set S 2 = {1, 2, . . . , N 2 } with the following probability transition [31]:
div.formula: Pr{r t+δ = j|r t = i, g t = α} = { π α ij (h)δ + o(δ), i ̸ = j, 1 + π α ii (h)δ + o(δ), i = j, where δ > 0 and lim h→0 o(δ)/δ = 0, π α ij (h) > 0(i ̸ = j)
div.p: is the transition rate from mode i at time t to mode j at time t+δ, and π α ii (h) = -Σ j̸ =i π α ij (h) < 0 for each i ∈ S 2 , here, h represents the sojourn time. Readers can refer to [32] for discrete-time case. The system matrix E is assumed to satisfy RankE = r ≤ n. For each g t = α and r t = i, A α,i , A dα,i , B α,i are known constant matrices with appropriate dimensions. In addition, it is satisfied that Rank(E) = Rank(E, B α,i ).
Throughout this paper, the generally uncertain TRs are considered, which specifically means the following two cases.
One is that π α ij (h) is completely unknown; the other is that π α ij (h) is not exactly known but upper and lower bounded, for example,
div.formula: π α ij (h) ∈ [π α ij , π α ij ]
div.p: , where π α ij and π α ij are known real constants representing the lower and upper bounds of π α ij (h), respectively. As for the second case, we further define
div.formula: π α ij (h) π α ij + ∆π α ij (h), in which π α ij = 1 2 (π α ij + π α ij ) and |∆π α ij (h)| ≤ λ α ij with λ α ij = 1 2 (π α ij -π α ij ).
div.p: For instance, the TR matrix with three jumping modes may be described as
div.formula: Π α =   π α 11 +
I i α,uk {j : π α ij is not known for j ∈ S 2 }.
div.p: Further, in this paper, we consider both I i α,k ̸ = ∅ and I i α,uk ̸ = ∅. Since I i α,k = ∅ or I i α,uk = ∅ represents a kind of extreme case that is too bad or too ideal, the considered case is more applicable in practical. Then, we can denote the following:
div.formula: I i α,k {k i α,1 , k i α,2 , . . . , k i α,m } 1 ≤ m < N 2 , where k i α,s (s ∈ {1, 2, . . . , m}) represents the index of s-th element in the i-th row of the TR matrix Π α . Remark 1: In Π α , we did not assume π α ii = - ∑ j̸ =i π α ij and πα ii = - ∑ j̸ =i
div.p: πα ij , so even though the upper and lower bounds of π α 11 (h) and π α 13 (h) are known, it does not mean the upper and lower bounds of π α 12 (h) are known. In addition, the uncertain TRs are divided into two parts according to their upper and lower bounds, one is a constant and the other is a small time-varying variable as adjustment. Instead of using their upper and lower bounds separately, this way of modeling will simplify the following discussion and make it more clear without reducing the conservativeness. As we can see, the unique way of modeling the generally uncertain TRs as in Π α will lay a solid foundation in the following proof of Theorem 1, it will show that the feasibility of sufficient conditions to ensure stability of the switching Semi-Markovian systems is fully dependents on the feasibility of modeling π α ij (h). Now, we consider the system (1) of the unforced form:
div.formula: E ẋ(t) = A(g t , r t )x(t) + A d (g t , r t )x(t -d).
div.p: Definition 1: [21] The system ( 2) is said to be:
div.formula: 1) regular if det(sE -A α,i ) is not identically zero for any α ∈ S 1 , i ∈ S 2 ; 2) impulse-free if deg{det(sE -A α,i )} = Rank(E)
div.p: for any α ∈ S 1 , i ∈ S 2 ; 3) exponentially mean-square stable if for any initial condition, there holds
div.formula: E{∥x(t)∥ 2 } ≤ ρe -β(t-t0) ∥x(t 0 )∥ 2 C , ∀t ≥ t 0 , for constants ρ > 0, β > 0, where ∥x(t 0 )∥ 2 C = sup -d≤θ≤0 {∥x(θ)∥ 2 , ∥ ẋ(θ)∥ 2 }; 4
div.p: ) stochastically admissible if it is regular, impulse-free and exponentially mean-square stable. Now, we choose two nonsingular matrices M and N
div.formula: such that M EN = [ I r 0 0 0 ] . Define M A α,i N = [ A α i1 A α i2 A α i3 A α i4 ] and M A dα,i N = [ A α di1 A α di2 A α di3 A α di4 ] . Since we have Rank(E) = Rank(E, B α,i ), it can be obtained that M B α,i = [ B α i1 0 ] . By transformation z(t) = N -1 x(t) = [ z 1 (t) z 2 (t)
div.p: ] , then the system (1) has the following equivalent form
div.formula: ż1 (t) = A α i1 z 1 (t) + A α i2 z 2 (t) + A α di1 z 1 (t -d) +A α di2 z 2 (t -d) + B α i1 u(t) (3a) 0 = A α i3 z 1 (t) + A α i4 z 2 (t) + A α di3 z 1 (t -d) +A α di4 z 2 (t -d) (3b) with initial condition ϕ(θ) = N -1 φ(θ) = col(ϕ 1 (θ), ϕ 2 (θ)).
div.p: By substuiting ϕ(t) into (3b), we have
div.formula: 0 = A α i3 ϕ 1 (t)+A α i4 ϕ 2 (t)+A α di3 ϕ 1 (t-d)+A α di4 ϕ 2 (t-d).(4)
div.p: Eq.( 4) is the compatible initial condition of the system (3), to ensure continuity of states at switching points (t = τ 1 , τ 2 , ..., τ k , ...), the following condition is always hold
div.formula: A α i3 z 1 (τ - k ) + A α i4 z 2 (τ - k ) + A α di3 z 1 (τ - k -d) +A α di4 z 2 (τ - k -d) = A α j3 z 1 (τ + k ) + A α j4 z 2 (τ + k ) +A α dj3 z 1 (τ + k -d) + A α dj4 z 2 (τ + k -d) (5)
div.p: Remark 2: As we all know, the analysis of continuoustime singular switching systems is more complicated than that of non-singular switching systems, including discretetime ones [24]. For such systems, the states are not complete, often, we can use a singular value decomposition approach to obtain dynamics decomposition form in the new coordinates, while in the state transformation process, there exists switching law induced state jumps for switched singular systems with mode-dependent singular matrices, see Figure 1 in [28]. Also, as discussed in [26,27,29], the accumulation of jumps can be destructive to the system. In this paper, we considered mode-independent singular matrix, which means at the each switching instant, the transformation matrix is the same, that is the state transformation is switching law independent, thus there is no state jumps for the states of differential part at switching instants, and we consider the situation where the state components for the algebraic part is also consistent when switching happens, this is ensured by ( 4) and ( 5), in which we can see the control input only affects on the differential equation and does not disturb the validity the algebraic equation, thus the continuity of states at switching points still hold. Definition 2: [22] We say that g t has an average dwell time T a if there exists a positive number N 0 such that the number of switches of g t in the interval (t 0 , t) denoted by N g (t 0 , t),
div.formula: satisfies N r (t 0 , t) ≤ N 0 + t-t0
div.p: Ta for all t ≥ t 0 ≥ 0, where N 0 is called a chatter bound.
Lemma 1: [23] Given any real number ε and any square matrix R, the matrix inequality ε(R+R T ) ≤ ε 2 F +RF -1 R T holds for any matrix F > 0.
Our purposes in this paper are to construct sufficient conditions for the stochastic admissibility of the system, and to synthesize a controller ensures the closed-loop system can be stabilizabe.

div.head: A. Stochastic stability analysis
div.p: The following theorem provides sufficient conditions on the stochastic admissibility of the system (2) with generally uncertain TRs.
Theorem 1: Given λ > 0, µ > 1, the system (2) with uncertain TRs is stochastically admissible if there exist nonsingular matrix P α,i , positive-definite symmetric matrices

Next, we prove the system (2) is exponentially meansquare stable. To this end, we select the following Lyapunov functional:
div.formula: V (x(t), g t , r t ) = 3 ∑ h=1 V h (x(t), g t , r t ),(13)

div.p: Ta , which means that system (2) is exponentially meansquare stable. According to Definition 1, the system (2) is exponentially mean-square admissible. Since we consider a generally uncertain TRs in this paper, the proof is then to divide them into the following two cases:
div.formula: (Case I) i ∈ I i α,k .
div.p: In this case, first, denote λ i α,k
div.formula: ∑ j∈I i α,k π α ij (h). S- ince I i α,uk ̸ = ∅, it holds λ i α,k < 0. Noticing that ∑ N2 j=1 π α ij (h)E T P α,j can be presented as N2 ∑ j=1 π α ij (h)E T P α,j =   ∑ j∈I i α,k + ∑ j∈I i α,uk   π α ij (h)E T P α,j = ∑ j∈I i α,k π α ij (h)E T P α,j -λ i α,k ∑ j∈I i α,uk π α ij (h) -λ i α,k E T P α,j ,(21)

div.formula: 0 ≤ π α ij (h)/ -λ i α,k ≤ 1 (j ∈ I i α,uk ) and ∑ j∈I i α,uk π α ij (h) -λ i α,k = 1. So for ∀l ∈ I i α,uk ,we have Γα i = ∑ j∈I i α,uk π α ij (h) -λ i α,k [Γ α i +diag{ ∑ j∈I i α,k π α ij (h)E T (P α,j -P α,l ), 0, 0} ] . Therefore, for 0 ≤ π α ij (h) ≤ -λ i α,k , Γα i < 0 is equivalent to Γ α i + diag{ ∑ j∈I i α,k π α ij (h)E T (P α,j -P α,l ), 0, 0} < 0. (22

div.p: while by virtue of Lemma 1, for any W α ij > 0, it follows that

div.p: From ( 22)-( 25), by applying Schur complement, (7a) guar-

In this case, similarly, denote λ i α,k ∑ j∈I α,k π α ij (h). Since I i α,k ̸ = ∅, it holds λ i α,k > 0. So for ∀l ∈ I i α,uk , l ̸ = i, Γα i = ∑ j∈I i α,uk ,j̸ =i π α ij (h) -π α ii (h) -λ i α,k [ Γ α i + diag { π α ii (h)E T (P α,i -P α,l ) + ∑ j∈I i α,k π α ij (h)E T (P α,j -P α,l ), 0, 0      . Therefore, for 0 ≤ π α ij (h) ≤ -π α ii (h) -λ i α,k , Γ α i < 0 is equivalent to Γ α i + diag { π α ii (h)E T (P α,i -P α,l ) + ∑ j∈I i α,k π α ij (h)E T (P α,j -P α,l ), 0, 0    < 0. (26
div.p: Since π α ii (h) < 0, (27) holds if we have E T (P α,i -P α,l ) ≥ 0,
div.formula: Γ α i + diag    ∑ j∈I i α,k π α ij (h)E T (P α,j -P α,l ), 0, 0    < 0. (27
div.p: As in ( 24) and ( 25), for any V α ij > 0, we also have
div.formula: ∑ j∈I i α,k π α ij (h)E T (P α,j -P α,l ) ≤ ∑ j∈I i α,k π α ij E T (P α,j -P α,l ) + ∑ j∈I i α,k [ (λ α ij ) 2 4 V α ij +E T (P α,j -P α,l )(V α ij ) -1 (P α,j -P α,l ) T E ] . (28
div.p: From ( 26)-( 28), we know (8a), (8c) guarantee Γ α i < 0 by applying Schur complement when i ∈ I i α,uk . Similar way to deal with
div.formula: ∑ N2 j=1 π ij (h)Q α,j -Q α ≤ 0.
div.p: In summary, the system (2) is stochastically admissible with generally uncertain TRs from the above analysis. This completes the proof.

Remark 3: As we can see from the proof, although the system switching and jumps of subsystems may happen simultaneously, the condition ( 17) still holds at switching instants because of the conditions in (9) and the situation where the states are consistent at switching instants.

Remark 4: Noting that [19] also considered MJSs with generally uncertain TRs, but the modeling and technique in dealing with uncertain TRs are totally different from ours in this paper. First, we considered a more generic topic on MJS with Semi-Markovian switching. Second, in modeling these uncertain TRs, [19] gave too much conservative constraints, such as the absolute values of upper and lower bounds of uncertainties are the same by assumption, while in this paper, we use an average method to estimate the upper and lower bounds of sojourn-time dependent TRs, which is more general. Third, the method in dealing with uncertain TRs in the proof is also different, our method is more general and is valid to deal with constant uncertain TRs case, while the method proposed in [19] is special and some assumptions in dealing with uncertain TRs are too conservative and not available in this paper.

Remark 5: Also, noting that [9,10] have dealt with stability of semi-Markov jump linear systems, in which less conservative results have been proposed by separating TRs into M sections. While they did not take into account of generally uncertain TRs in the jumping processes, considering this, the partition method is no longer reducing conservativeness for the complexity of computational burden and this method is only available when the upper and lower bounds of all TRs are known. On the other hand, as pointed in [25], the main proposition in to partition the sojourn-time into M sections in each working mode is relatively conservative and practically infeasible.

div.head: B. Controller design
div.p: In order to ensure the system can be stabilizable, the following feedback controller is proposed

Obviously, it holds that 0 ≤ (P T α,i B α,i B T α,i -H α,i )H -1 α,i (P T α,i B α,i B T α,i -H α,i ) T , which implies -P T α,i B α,i B T α,i H -1 α,i B α,i B T α,i P α,i ≤ -P T α,i B α,i B T α,i -B α,i B T α,i P α,i + H α,i
div.p: . So, the conditions in Theorem 2 can guarantee the closedloop system with generally uncertain TRs is stochastically admissible.

Remark 6: Noticing that when g(t) = {1}, the switching S-MJS turns into a norm singular S-MJS, which has been studied in [30]. In this case, the above Theorems are also valid for checking the stochastic stability and stabilization of singular S-MJLS by setting α ≡ 1.

Remark 7: It can be seen from the Theorem 2, the controller gain matrices are easy to obtain by solving these LMI conditions, and the analysis in the proof is also simple and clear because we avoid using P -1 α,i with which will cause big trouble in linearizating these matrix inequalities to eliminate P α,i so as to obtain state feedback gain matrices. Of course, we can use the similar method to tackle this problem provided in [33] with constant TRs.

div.head: Consider the switching Markovian jump system 1 with parameters
div.p: The generally uncertain TR matrix is given as follows:   -2.8 + ∆π For switching Markovian jump system 2 the parameters

The generally uncertain TR matrix is given as follows:   ? 1.0 + ∆π V. CONCLUSIONS this paper, the problems of stochastic stability and stabilization for singular switching S-MJSs with generally uncertain TRs have been investigated. Firstly, by employing Lyapunov theory, sufficient conditions that ensure the system to be stochastically admissible are given in the form of LMIs. Then, a mode-dependent state feedback controller has been designed to stabilize the system. Finally, a numerical example has been provided to show the effectiveness of the proposed results.
